@villebro I tried this out and it worked really well even without the Drill PR!  I think pretty much the only thing that Drill needs now for the integration is the time grains!  Thanks for your help with this.  
LGTM +1

Thanks for verifying that this works @cgivre . @mistercrunch @john-bodley @betodealmeida would really appreciate help reviewing this, as I think this is one of the last hurdles to being able to support engines that rely on the presence of non-standard characters in schema/table names.

Stumbled upon this as well, and looks like the stacking is sorted by metric name in ABC order. I.e. renaming a metric will shift it's position in the stack. Worked for Bar chart, may work for other charts as well. Not optimal, but doable.

Also, did you check a curl on localhost:8082? Anyway, if possible I'd close this github issue (since it should be only to report bugs) and follow up with the community support on slack (https://apache-superset.slack.com), you'll find more support in there :)

Hi there, I'm encountering the same problem. @rjurney, any outcomes from your investigation?

Hi, my `superset db upgrade` hangs up on the following migration:
```INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Running upgrade 6c7537a6004a -> cefabc8f7d38, Increase size of name column in ab_view_menu```
I guess it's related to this bug? I tried to fix the issue by upgrading Superset from `jdbertron:master` but it didn't help. Would you be able to help me out? I'm using Google Cloud MySQL.

OK, thanks for your consideration, but definitely don't block on this right now.

I just spent some time looking at this, and unfortunately _if I'm interpreting things correctly_ the current  superset architecture--notably the stuff in `superset/__init__.py`--won't allow us to test a lot of things easily or elegantly (or at all). Simply importing the `superset` package has a ton of side effects, including creation of a single, global flask application itself.  My guess is by the time any test runs it will already have a fully constructed application that depends on all side effects of all of the global code in that `__init__.py`, so mocking the value and changing it in a test won't affect the actual pre-constructed-at-import-time behavior of the endpoint methods.

Side note: I think some minor investment in refactoring `superset/__init__.py` so that it exposes types and functions etc but _doesn't actually construct or do anything_ until you ask it to would be great.  Then tests would be able to tweak things and construct a new app for testing under the new construction parameters.
We would appreciate it if you could provide us with more info about this issue/pr! Please do not leave the `title` or `description` empty.
@jeepxiaozi thank you for the fix! Could you create a pull request to the apache project please? :)

I've submitted #7482, but needs FAB>2.1. This PR has no breaking changes.

For the deprecation of the old REST API attached on the ``ModelView's``, I'll be submitting code to replace them. Currently Superset's ``setup.py`` is pinned under the deprecation version. 
But I would say that this is a different problem outside the context of this SIP.

@diggidydave I’m not certain how much the current architecture is tied to Flask-AppBuilder but I’m used [this](https://github.com/sloria/cookiecutter-flask/blob/master/%7B%7Bcookiecutter.app_name%7D%7D/%7B%7Bcookiecutter.app_name%7D%7D/app.py) approach (in addition to blueprints) for constructing a number of Flask apps which may help to remedy the issue.

I like that pattern @john-bodley ... an app factory func plus setup methods that require you to hand them an instance (rather than rely on global/singleton state) would improve the situation greatly. When I get some cycles I may look into how much work that would end up being. 

In the meanwhile @graceguo-supercat 👍
Awesome, thanks.

@DiggidyDave I think the challenge with using global variables outside of the configs is it makes it somewhat harder to augment `ENABLE_EXPLORE_JSON_CSRF_PROTECTION` via configuration changes as it requires re-importing the file to test the `is_feature_enabled(..._)`. One could mock the `EXPLORE_JSON_METHODS` object though it feels less clean.

I want to add test that links configuration `ENABLE_EXPLORE_JSON_CSRF_PROTECTION` with methods allowed in `/explore_json/` endpoint. The approach that uses global variable seems hard to have unit test.

@DiggidyDave Given it's a little hard to write unit test with global variable:

> EXPLORE_JSON_METHODS = ['POST']
>     if not is_feature_enabled('ENABLE_EXPLORE_JSON_CSRF_PROTECTION'):
>           EXPLORE_JSON_METHODS.append('GET')

 are you ok with no unit test with this solution?

what can`t be done ?

If you just need Superset to work with Okta, here's a quick workaround: https://gist.github.com/ktmud/2475282a166893e5d17039c308cbe50d

OpenID Connect is basically just OAuth 2.0, so `AUTH_OAUTH` from Flask-Appbuilder should already work.
Be careful Superset should not use ``flask fab security-cleanup``, since it will delete all permissions that are not associated with any view (all datasource access, all database access, etc...)

Place to start (filters added): http://localhost:8088/tablemodelview/list/?_flt_0_database=1 Old State: When you add filters the search button appears: When you clear those filters, as you can see in the screenshot below you are stuck with a filtered list of tables: In the current state the only way to render an unfiltered list of list of tables is to refresh the page, which would be step 3 but I am omitting because it would require a refresh and I'm trying to draw the distinction. That's unintuitive to some business users. Since the cursor is already there, it would be better if they could simply refresh with the same button. One could argue that clearing filters prompts a refresh, but if you have as many tables as we do, you don't want to do that unless you want to do that if you catch my drift. So, here's the new version from this PR: start with a filter: Clear the filter and you still have control (see new button) And after clicking the refresh button (you get unfiltered results) : Let me know if this makes sense.
concern on the amount of polling requests, i think #7498 might be better.

Having noted this inactivity too, I'd like to know the following (since the result of geocoding is a point geometry):

Are there any plans to integrate geometry data types (see point, linestring, polygon, etc. from OGC) and the PostGIS extension of PostgreSQL into Superset?

You can do that but you need to add an aggregation to your data even if it is not required in the metrics sections.

So that the metrics section looks like SUM(levels) or whatever aggregation you chose. Then you need to set the time grain to 5 minutes.
